awd_titl_txt: Flexible Statistical Modelling for High Dimensional Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientific and technology innovations have made massive high-dimensional data ubiquitous in various fields, such as biological science, medical studies, public health, social sciences, e-commerce, finance, climate studies, and so on. During the past decade statisticians have developed a rich collection of new tools for high-dimensional statistical modeling. Despite these important advances, there are still many challenges and open problems to be dealt with in high-dimensional data analysis. Their solutions require innovative ideas and techniques to handle the methodological, computational and theoretical challenges. The goal of this research is to develop mathematically solid and computationally efficient methods to address these pressing and important inferential challenges. 

This research consists of three projects. The first project concerns measurement errors in high-dimensional M-estimation. The PI will study a new unified convex approach to solve the error-in-variables penalized M-regression including Huber regression, logistic regression, quantile regression, and the support vector machine. In the second project the PI will establish a new inference tool named composite M-estimation and demonstrate its applications in high-dimensional learning. In the third project the PI will study a flexible heterogeneity pursuit method for understanding the heterogeneity effects in high-dimensional data. Software packages will be created to make the new methods readily available to other researchers and practitioners.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
In this project we developed flexible and powerful statistical learning methods for high-dimensional data. One main thread of research focused on predictive and classification methods. We developed several novel high-dimensional regression methods under realistic but messy conditions such as skewed data, heavy tailed data, truncated response or heterogeneity. The standard regression methods fail to perform well under those settings, while the developed new regression methods can deliver excellent and satisfactory results. We developed several new classification methods. Some was built to demonstrate a new theoretical framework for classification and some was proposed as the state-of-the-art classifier for tensor classification.  The other main thread of research was modern modern multivariate analysis. For example, we developed the first exactly uncorrelated PCA and the first rank canonical correlation analysis for survival data. Our research encountered some computational challenges, and we successfully developed efficient algorithms to address these challenges. Our research also shed new lights on cross-validation when the data have measurement error and showed an efficient way to conduct leave-one-out cross-validation. This project contributed to the training of several Ph.D. students who were members of the research team. They graduated during the funding period and got their first job in IT industry or in academia. This project produced a series of papers and some works were presented at invited seminars and conferences. In addition, all the developed methods were implemented in publicly available software.

 


Last Modified: 08/13/2023
Modified by: Hui Zou
